awd_titl_txt: Conference: Travel Support for Conference on Mathematical Relativity
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support travel for young US scientists to the "Mathematical Relativity: Past, Present, Future" workshop at the Erwin Schrödinger International Institute (ESI), December 4-7, 2023, in Vienna, Austria. The goal of the workshop is to bring together advanced doctoral students, promising young researchers, and leading experts in the field to discuss the recent developments in the area, to share and discuss techniques that have proven particularly successful, to assess new areas of contact, and to support existing and promote new collaborations. This event will allow the participants to create a professional network, and this professional network promotes information sharing, collaboration, and career development while incubating meaningful contributions to the field. One third of the speakers at the conference are women. The committee which will choose the US participates is committed to choosing a diverse community of outstanding researchers in the field.

The workshop will focus on several major recent breakthroughs in mathematical general relativity, including the long-awaited proof of the stability of the Kerr solution for small angular momenta, new initial data gluing methods and proofs of the positive energy theorem, as well as insights to canonical structures of initial data for Einstein’s equations (with or without coupling to matter fields). The workshop will gather young researchers along with leaders in the field of mathematical relativity. The workshop honors the 100th birthday of Yvonne Choquet-Bruhat, one of the outstanding pioneers of the field of mathematical relativity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Final report for NSF grant 2333999

 

The purpose of this NSF grant was to provide travel and lodging support for young researchers based in the United States so that they could attend two research conferences involving gravitational physics.

1) "Mathematical Relativity: The Past, the Present and the Future"

The conference took place at the Schrödinger Institute in Vienna, Austria, December 4-7, 2023. The website for the conference was

  https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://www.esi.ac.at/events/e526/__;!!C5qS4YX3!BXUwbzQ32iTi8sNEu-P_bnzE4QmqHC2PgxSCVPAiiVidWHgi8XeLIHQOSlw3YICq9IF0wEGVD-11_AdGR_Nddmusl8D7lDV9VA$

 

2) 17th Marcel Grossman meeting. The conference took place in Pescara, Italy, July 7-12, 2024. The website for this conference can be accessed by googling "17th Marcel Grossman meeting".

 

For both conferences, an advertisement requesting applications, along with recommendations from advisors of the applicants, was posted through the American Physical Society’s Division of Gravitational Physics. For the first conference, the successful applicants were chosen by a committee consisting of Piotr Chrusciel, Michael Eichmair, and Gerhard Huisken along with the PI. For the second conference, the successful applicants were chosen by the PI.

The successful applicants for the first conference, along with the amount of the amount of support each received, is listed as follows:

a) Nishanth Gudapati (Clark University) [$1,178.52]

b) Sven Hirsch (Institute for Advanced Study) [$2,514.18]

c) Andrea Nutzi (Stanford University) [$2,132.75]

d) Rodrigo Andrade E Silva (University of Maryland) [$1,885.14]

The successful applicant for the second conference, along with the amount of support each received, is listed as follows:

a) Siddharth Ajith (University of Virginia) [$2,335.61]

b) Logan Fisher (Lehigh University) [$1,351.12]

c) Brian Luczak (Vanderbilt University) [$2,129.52]

The proposal for this grant originally was intended for travel support for young researchers to attend the conference “Mathematical Relativity: The Past, the Present and the Future”. Because the successful applicants for travel support to this conference did not need to use all the money in the grant, there was extra money left, so it was decided, with the approval of the program director for gravitational physics at the NSF, to offer this remaining money for travel support to young researchers to attend the Marcel Grossman meeting. All the money in the grant was applied to travel support to young researchers for both of these conferences.

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: James A Isenberg
